column1: Wiesbaden (German pronunciation: [ˈviːsˌbaːdn̩] (listen)) is a city in central western Germany and the capital of the federal state of Hesse. As of June 2020
column2: it had 290
column3: 955  inhabitants
column5: 000 United States citizens (mostly associated with the United States Army). The Wiesbaden urban area is home to approx. 560
column6: 000 people.

column2: together with nearby Frankfurt am Main
column3: Darmstadt
column5: is part of the Frankfurt Rhine Main Region
column6: a metropolitan area with a combined population of about 5.8 million people.

column1: Wiesbaden is one of the oldest spa towns in Europe. Its name translates to "meadow baths"
column2: a reference to its famed hot springs. It is  also internationally famous for its architecture and climate—it is also called the "Nice of the North" in reference to the city in France. At one time
column3: Wiesbaden boasted 26 hot springs. As of 2008
column4: fourteen of the springs are still flowing.In 1970
column5: the town hosted the tenth Hessentag Landesfest (English: Hessian Day
column6: a state festival).

column1: The city is considered the tenth richest in Germany (2014) boasting 110.3% of the national average gross domestic product in 2017. The average annual buying power per citizen is €24
Wiesbaden is situated on the right (northern) bank of the Rhine
column2: below the confluence of the Main
column3: where the Rhine's main direction changes from north to west. The city is across the Rhine from Mainz
column4: the capital of the federal state of Rhineland-Palatinate. Frankfurt am Main is located about 38 kilometres (23.6 mi) east. To the north of the city are the Taunus Mountains
column5: which trend in a northeasterly direction.

column2: the Stadtmitte
column3: is located in the north-easternmost part of the Upper Rhine Valley at the spurs of the Taunus mountains
column4: about 5 kilometres (3.1 mi) from the Rhine. The landscape is formed by a wide lowland between the Taunus heights in the north
column5: the Bierstadter Höhe and the Hainerberg in the east
column6: the Mosbacher Mountain in the south
column7: and the Schiersteiner Mountain in the west
column8: an offshoot of the Taunus range. The downtown is drained only by the narrow valley of the Salzbach
column10: on the eastern flanks of the Mosbacher Mountain. The city's main railway line and the Mainz road (Mainzer Straße) follow this valley. Several other streams drain into the Salzbach within the city center: the Wellritzbach
column15: as well as the outflow of many thermal and mineral springs in the Kurhaus (spa) district. Above the city center
column16: the Salzbach is better known as the Rambach.

column1: The highest point of the Wiesbaden municipality is located northwest of the city center near the summit of the Hohe Wurzel
column2: with an elevation of 608 metres (1
column3: 995 ft) above sea level. The lowest point is the harbour entrance of Schierstein at 83 metres (272 ft) above sea level. The central square (the Schlossplatz
column4: or palace square) is at an elevation of 115 metres (377 ft).

column1: Wiesbaden covers an area of 204 km2 (79 sq mi). It is 17.6 kilometres (10.9 mi) from north to south and 19.7 kilometres (12.2 mi) from west to east. In the north are vast forest areas
column2: which cover 27.4% of the urban area. In the west and east are vineyards and agricultural land
column3: which cover 31.1% of the area. Of the municipality's 79 kilometres (49.1 mi)-long border
column4: the Rhine makes up 10.3 kilometres (6.4 mi).

column1: Wiesbaden has a temperate-oceanic climate (Köppen: Cfb) with relatively cold winters and warm summers. Its average annual temperature is 9.8 °C (49.6 °F)
column2: with monthly mean temperatures ranging from 1.0 °C (33.8 °F) in January to 18.6 °C (65.5 °F) in July.

column1: While evidence of settlement at present-day Wiesbaden dates back to the Neolithic era
column2: historical records document continuous occupancy after the erection of a Roman fort in 6 AD which housed an auxiliary cavalry unit. The thermal springs of Wiesbaden are first mentioned in Pliny the Elder's Naturalis Historia. They were famous for their recreation pools for Roman army horses and possibly as the source of a mineral used for red hair dye (which was very fashionable around the turn of BC/AD among women in Rome).The Roman settlement is first mentioned using the name Aquae Mattiacorum (Latin for "Waters of the Mattiaci") in 121. The Mattiaci were a Germanic tribe
column3: possibly a branch of the neighboring Chatti
column4: who lived in the vicinity at that time. The town also appears as Mattiacum in Ptolemy's Geographia (2.10). The Roman Empire built the Limes Germanicus
column5: which was a line of Roman frontier fortifications in the Taunus. Wiesbaden is just south of the Taunus.

column1: The capital of the province of Germania Superior
column2: Mogontiacum (present-day Mainz)
column3: base of 2 (at times 3) Roman legions
column4: was just over the Rhine and connected by a bridge at the present-day borough of Mainz-Kastel (Roman "castellum")
column5: a strongly fortified bridgehead.

column2: a coalition of Germanic tribes from beyond the Limes
column3: captured the fort around 260. Later
column5: when the Romans and Alamanni were allied
column6: the Alemanni gained control of the Wiesbaden area and were in charge of its defense against other Germanic tribes.

column1: After the Franks under Clovis I defeated the Alamanni in the Battle of Tolbiac in 496
column2: the Franks eventually displaced the Alamanni in the Wiesbaden area over the course of the 6th century. In the 8th century
column3: Wiesbaden became the site of a royal palace of the Frankish kingdom. The first documented use of the name Wiesbaden is by Einhard
column5: whose writings mention "Wisabada" sometime between 828 and 830.

column1: When the Frankish Carolingian Empire broke up in 888
column2: Wiesbaden was in the eastern half
column3: called East Francia (which would evolve into the Holy Roman Empire). The town was part of Franconia
column4: the heartland of East Francia. In the 1170s
column5: the Count of Nassau
column6: Walram I
column7: received the area around Wiesbaden as a fiefdom. When Franconia fragmented in the early 13th century
column8: Nassau emerged as an independent state as part of the Holy Roman Empire.

column2: an imperial city
column3: of the Holy Roman Empire. However

column1: Wiesbaden returned to the control of the House of Nassau in 1270 under Count Walram II
column2: Count of Nassau. However
column3: Wiesbaden and the castle at Sonnenberg were again destroyed in 1283 in conflict with Eppstein.

column1: Walram's son and successor Adolf would later become king of Germany from 1292 until 1298. In 1329
column2: under Adolf's son Gerlach I of Nassau-Weilburg the House of Nassau and thereby
column3: Wiesbaden
column4: received the right of coinage from Holy Roman Emperor Louis the Bavarian.

column2: the County of Nassau-Weilburg was divided among the sons of Gerlach. The County of Nassau's holdings would be subdivided many times among heirs
column3: with the parts being brought together again whenever a line died out. Wiesbaden became the seat of the County of Nassau-Wiesbaden under Count Adolf I (1307–1370)
column4: eldest son of Gerlach. It would eventually fell back to Nassau-Weilburg in 1605.

column1: Due to its participation in the uprisings of the German Peasants' War of 1525
column2: Wiesbaden lost all its privileges for over 40 years. During this time
column3: Wiesbaden became Protestant with the nomination of Wolf Denthener as first Lutheran pastor on January 1
column5: the first Latin school was opened
column6: preparing pupils for the gymnasium in Idstein. In 1566
column7: the privileges of the city were restored.

column1: The oldest remaining building of Wiesbaden
column2: the old city hall
column3: was built in 1609 and 1610. No older buildings are preserved due to two fires in 1547 and 1561. In 1648
column4: at the end of the devastating Thirty Years' War
column5: chronicles tell that Wiesbaden had barely 40 residents left. In 1659
column6: the County of Nassau-Weilburg was divided again. Wiesbaden became part of the County of Nassau-Usingen. In 1744
column7: the seat of Nassau-Usingen was moved to Biebrich. In 1771
column8: the Count of Nassau-Usingen granted a concession for gambling in Wiesbaden. In 1810
column9: the Wiesbaden Casino (German: Spielbank) was opened in the old Kurhaus. Gambling was later outlawed by Prussian authorities in 1872.

column1: As a result of Napoleon's victory over Austria in the Battle of Austerlitz
column2: the Holy Roman Empire was dissolved in 1805. On July 12
column5: including the remaining counties of Nassau-Usingen and Nassau-Weilburg
column6: formally left the Holy Roman Empire and joined together in the Confederation of the Rhine. Napoleon was its "protector". Under pressure from Napoleon
column7: both counties merged to form the Duchy of Nassau on August 30

column2: the Duchy of Nassau joined the German Confederation. The capital of Nassau was moved from Weilburg to Wiesbaden
column3: and the city became the ducal residence. Building activity started to give the city a magnificent appearance. Most of the historical center of Wiesbaden dates back to this time.
000 citizens of Nassau assembled in Wiesbaden on March 4. They demanded a constitution from the Duke

column2: Nassau took Austria's side. This decision led to the end of the duchy. After the Austrian defeat
column3: Nassau was annexed by Prussia and became part of the Prussian province of Hesse-Nassau. The deposed duke Adolph of Nassau in 1890 became the Grand Duke of Luxembourg (see House of Nassau). This turned out to be a fortunate change for the city
column4: as it then became an international spa town. A rise in construction commenced after the aristocracy followed the lead of the Hohenzollern emperors
column5: who began annual trips to Wiesbaden.

column1: The period around the turn of the 20th century is regarded as the heyday of the city. Kaiser Wilhelm II visited the city regularly in summer
column2: such that it became an unofficial "summer residence". The city was also popular among the Russian nobility. In the wake of the imperial court
column3: numerous nobles
column5: and wealthy businessmen increasingly settled in the city. Many wealthy persons chose Wiesbaden as their retirement seat
column6: as it offered leisure and medical treatment alike. In the latter part of the 19th century
column7: Wiesbaden became the German city with the most millionaires.In 1894
column8: the present Hessian State Theater
column9: designed by the Vienna architects Fellner and Helmer
column10: was built on behalf of Kaiser Wilhelm II.

column2: Wiesbaden fell under the Allied occupation of the Rhineland and was occupied by the French army in 1918. In 1921
column3: the Wiesbaden Agreement on German reparations to France was signed in the city. In 1925
column4: Wiesbaden became the headquarters of the British Army of the Rhine until the withdrawal of occupying forces from the Rhineland in 1930.

column1: In the Kristallnacht pogrom on November 10
column3: Wiesbaden's large synagogue on Michelsberg was destroyed. The synagogue had been designed by Phillip Hoffmann and built in 1869. Another synagogue in Wiesbaden-Bierstadt was also destroyed. When the Nazis came to power in Germany
column5: 700 Jews living in Wiesbaden. By June 1942 nearly all of them had been deported to the death camps in Poland.General Ludwig Beck from Wiesbaden was one of the planners of the July 20
column6: 1944 assassination attempt of Adolf Hitler. Beck was designated by his fellow conspirators to be future Head of State (Regent) after elimination of Hitler. The plot failed
column8: and Beck was forced to commit suicide. Today
column9: the city annually awards the Ludwig Beck prize for civil courage in his honor.

The attack started at 0100 and by early afternoon the two forces of the 80th U.S. Infantry Division had linked up with the loss of only three dead and three missing. The Americans captured 900 German soldiers and a warehouse full of 4

The Schloßplatz ("palace square") is situated in the center of the city
column2: surrounded by several outstanding buildings. The ducal palace was begun under William
column3: Duke of Nassau. Its foundations were laid in 1837 and it was completed in November 1841 (two years after William's death). For the twenty-six remaining years of ducal authority it was the residence of the ruling family. It later served as a secondary residence for the King of Prussia 1866 to 1918. It was later used as a headquarters for French and British occupying forces after World War I
column5: the building has served as Landtag (parliamentary building) for the federal state of Hesse. The site of the palace had been that of a castle
column6: probably from the early Middle Ages
column7: around which the city had developed. While nothing is known of the former castle
column8: remains of it were uncovered during excavations after World War II.

column1: The Protestant Marktkirche ("market church") was built from 1852 to 1862 in a neo-Gothic style. Its western steeple is 92 metres (302 feet) in height

column1: The monumental Neo-Classical Kurhaus ("spa house") was built at the request of Kaiser Wilhelm II between 1904 and 1907. Its famous Spielbank (casino) is again in operation.
In front of the Kurhaus is a lawn known as the Bowling Green. To one side of the Bowling Green is the Kurhaus Kolonnade. Built in 1827
column2: the 129 meter structure is the longest hall in Europe supported by pillars. To the other side is the Theater Kolonnade

column1: The city of Wiesbaden is divided into 26 boroughs: five in the central city and 21 suburban districts. The 21 suburban districts were incorporated in four phases from 1926 to 1977. The former right Mainz suburbs Amöneburg
column2: Kastel and Kostheim have belonged to Wiesbaden since 1945.

column1: Frankfurt AirportThe city can be accessed from around the world via Frankfurt Airport (Flughafen Frankfurt am Main) which is located 15 kilometres (9.3 miles) east of Wiesbaden. The airport has four runways and serves 265 non-stop destinations. Run by transport company Fraport it ranks among the world's 10 busiest airports by passenger traffic and is the second busiest airport by cargo traffic in Europe. The airport also serves as a hub for Condor and as the main hub for German flag carrier Lufthansa. Depending on whether total passengers or flights are used
column2: it ranks second or third busiest in Europe alongside London Heathrow Airport and Paris Charles de Gaulle Airport. Passenger traffic at Frankfurt Airport in 2011 was 56.5 million.

column1: The airport can be reached by car or train and has two railway stations
column2: one for regional and one for long-distance traffic. The S-Bahn lines S8 and S9 (direction Offenbach Ost or Hanau Hbf) departing at the regional train station take 30 minutes from the airport to Wiesbaden Central Station
column3: the ICE trains departing at the long-distance railway station take also 30 minutes to the central station.

column2: Frankfurt Hahn Airport (Flughafen Frankfurt-Hahn) is not located anywhere near Frankfurt but is instead situated approximately 100 km (62 mi) from the city in Lautzenhausen (Rhineland-Palatinate). Hahn Airport was a major base for low-cost carrier Ryanair
column3: and now this has  been moved to Frankfurt Airport. This airport can be reached by car or bus. The nearest train station is in Traben-Trarbach
column4: it is ca. 17 km (11 mi) from the airport
column5: on foot. The roads are not lit.
